title: Cruz, A's avoid arbitration
subtitle: Cruz, A's avoid arbitration
body: OAKLAND, Calif. (AP) -- Right-hander Juan Cruz and the A's agreed to a $575,000, one-year contract on Monday, avoiding salary arbitration.  Cruz, acquired last offseason from Atlanta in the deal that sent Tim Hudson to the Braves, struggled in his first season with the A's. He went 0-3 with a 7.44 ERA in 28 relief appearances, allowing five home runs in 32 2-3 innings.  He was sent down to the Minors on June 17 and went 5-1 with a 2.40 ERA in 13 starts with Triple-A Sacramento before being recalled to the Majors inSeptember. In five seasons with Oakland, Atlanta and the Chicago Cubs, Cruz is 14-24 with a 4.36 ERA.   Cruz can also receive up to $50,000 in bonuses based on appearances. He would get $15,000 for making 45 appearances, an additional $15,000 for 50 appearances, and $20,000 more for 55 games pitched.   The A's previously agreed to one-year deals with outfielders Milton Bradley and Bobby Kielty and reliever Kiko Calero. They have two more arbitration-eligible players yet to be signed: catcher Adam Melhuse and second baseman Mark Ellis.
